column2: The official name, usually as registered with the Charity Commission.
column3: There's not a fixed taxonomy, but try to use the existing names and separate multiple tags with &
column7: The registration number with the Charity Commission of England & Wales
column8: Does it accept donations from the public? E.g. certain trusts for specific donors wouldn't do this. Any entry in here *must* start with Yes or No

column10: This is for when a charity has multiple projects and we've split the analysis up. The Overall category is for the aggregate.
column11: the official timeperiod covered by the report in question.
column13: I.e. is gift aid available? (so for example if it's a multinational group with a U.K. entity, then the answer would be "Yes")
column14: Charity Commission activity classification WHAT
column15: Charity Commission activity classification WHO
column16: Charity Commission activity classification HOW
column17: Link to the charity's page on the charity commission website. Only relevant for those which are registered with the charity commission - or if it's a registered charity in Scotland show the relevant page on the OSCR website, and similarly for the charity commission of Northern Ireland
column18: Source 1: URL - this is typically going to be the annual report from the charity commission website
column20: Comments/more detail - e.g. page reference for the number of beneficiaries or anything that was particularly hard to find
column21: number, usually listed in the prose
column22: units of impact; where there is a noun which would have to change to singular, indicate the singular in brackets; try to keep this to about 2 words, and certainly no more than 5 words long
column23: Expand on the short version in a way that clarifies the short version. This could involve explaining more about what the short version means, and also indicating things like whether it's an average over lots of different projects or just refers to one project
column24: Sometimes the accounts will refer to "indirect beneficiaries" - include those here. Alternatively include the knock-on impacts or second order impacts in this column
column25: units of impact; where there is a noun which would have to change to singular, this should be the first word; try to be descriptive, even if this makes it a bit on the long side

column33: units of impact; where there is a noun which would have to change to singular, this should be the first word; try to be descriptive, even if this makes it a bit on the long side
column34: This is the overall total costs
column35: Income from beneficiaries - should include income that's generated by activity that helps beneficiaries (typically selling things to beneficiaries). Accounting guidelines encourage charities to show grant funds as "income from charitable activities", so the figures labelled as "income from charitable activities" in accounts are often not what we need. Reviewing the figures by looking at the notes to the accounts often provides the level of detail needed to judge this correctly. Looking for reason to believe that if this funding disappeared, the charity has the option to simply not do the activity any more.
column36: May be labelled as something like "costs of generating voluntary income"
column37: How much of the "cost" quoted was spent on revenue generating trading/business of the charity. Doesn't include trading where the counterparty of the trade is a beneficiary of the charity (i.e. where the trading *is* part of the charitable work) - this would be income from charitable activities instead)
column38: We deduct the money spent on trading and fundraising to find the money spent on the beneficiaries. The reason for this is just simplicity: if money spent fundraising and on trading just raised itself over again, it'd be the same as if it'd just sat in the bank that year, appearing neither on the cost nor income ledgers.
column45: If the cost per beneficiary calclauted in the spreadsheet is an upper bound for the true cost say yes here otherwise leave blank
column46: Explain here if any changes to the calc of cost per ben/output/outcome. Leave blank if no adhoc adjustment
column48: For UK charities only - look only at the UK-specific entity only. If there is no UK entity, enter zero, because there's zero income coming to a uk entity
column49: For UK charities only - look only at the UK-specific entity only. If there is no UK entity, enter zero, because there's zero income coming to a uk entity
column50: Amount of reserves is usually stated in the "wordy bit" (c first half of the accounts)
column52: Source (ie which page number in the accounts) ; what is the target level of the reserves, and how does this compare. If you notice any risks such as underisked pension schemes or FX risk, then mention those here too
column54: Where a charity has several projects, we may have to choose one as the representative project. For really big mega-charities, it may be necessary to have the "representative" row being an aggregate or "average" of all the projects
column55: Is there enough data to include in the SoGive app? A judgement
column56: An indicator of the confidence we have in the data, especially the cost per impact
column57: Why?
column58: About one sentence long
column59: About 2-3 paragraphs long
column60: This is the qualitative bit about what your donation achieves. Stories about beneficiaries (either as a link, or copied and pasted - if copied and pasted also include a source). Sometimes this is available in the annual report and accounts, but may need to look on the charity's website
column63: A link to an image of a beneficiary. Sometimes this is available in the annual report and accounts, but may need to look on the charity's website
column64: A link to an image of a beneficiary. Sometimes this is available in the annual report and accounts, but may need to look on the charity's website
column65: Note - we might not need this; this will probably be deleted

column68: where we heard about the charity. OK to leave this blank

column25: people (singular: person) with cancer surviving
column47: Currently using the comment in the accounts that say that it employs more than 4000 researchers. This seems to result in a slightly high cost per researcher though, although it might be right. I have asked C R UK about this, and they have not been able to answer the question, so I will stick with this figure. The £2.1m of income from charitable activities is for cancer information and policy outreach. There is a further £87m for "research", however I'm inclined to think this is probably not income from charitable activites under the sogive definition
column52: The policy is for 3-5 months spend, and the charity has (to its credit) published its view that it should hold no more than 5 months' spend. Its current level is 5.7 months (according to its calcs - more like 6 months under my calcs, not sure why they are different, but it's not so important). CRUK explains in the accounts that has plans for the reserves to run down over time. Taking a forward-looking view like this is best practice for reserves management. The figures come from P23 of the accounts.
column53: funded XXXX hours/days/weeks of cancer research
column55: No - some data issues to reconsider around research charities, e.g. around how to convert money into time that might be measured in different units (minutes/hours/days/etc)
column57: The cost shown is based on CR UK funding 4000 researchers for a cost of £600m, minus some deductions to get to £400m. It is not clear whether this is right, for example, those 4000 researchers might include some who are partfunded by other organisations, or it may be that there are 4000 "inhouse" cruk researchers, but CRUK also funds some researchers who work externally, and some of the cruk funds are also partfunding some other researchers outside of the 4000 mentioned in the accounts. When I contacted CRUK for clarity on this, they were unable to clarify the situation
column58: A UK charity which primarily funds cancer research
column67: Request sent via website on 25 Jan 2016 asking for a conversation to talk about how they look at impact. Site says they will reply in 5 days. Reply sent on 15th Feb (while I was travelling, so I didn't see it for a while). The response included several paragraphs, but not one referred to how they assess impact, and I infer that they do not do this. Response email sent on 6th Mar asking about how to compare costs with number of researchers. The people I spoke with demonstrated themselves to be poorly equipped to deal with these questions.
column74: Lots of really high impact, but perhaps very comfortably funded already? Givewell has done an initial analysis of this question: http://blog.givewell.org/2014/01/15/returns-to-life-sciences-funding/

column47: Cost per beneficiary looks materially cheaper than the previous set of accounts (2013 accounts) but this is proabbly because we were only capturing a subset of the beneficiaries from that set of accounts, whereas this set of accounts counts up all the beneficiaries. Breakdown is provided: 2m people living with cancer, 0.6m carers, 3.2m family and friends. The information on the page in the accounts shows that these people reached are a mixture, some receiving a relatively "intensive" intervention, such as help from a nurse, but others are just calling a helpline, or even just seeing info on a website
column52: To Macmillan's credit, they state a target range, including the level at which they consider their reserves to be "too high", and this threshold is £30m. The actual reserves are only marginally above this, and as the threshold they have set is not very high compared with the overall spend of the charity, this does not seem to constitute a worry, or a reason to avoid donating to this charity.

column60: Over one billion people are affected by neglected tropical diseases (NTDs). These include blinding trachoma, river blindness (onchocerciasis), lymphatic filariasis (also called elephantiasis), schistosomiasis (also called bilharzia) and soil transmitted helminthiasis (a variety of intestinal worms).
column61: Sightsavers has been tackling Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs) since 2011. Their work in this area not only tackles blindness but also has other health benefits, and is so cost-effective that even a small donation will likely improve the lives of many people.
column65: Evans, from Gyankobaa in the Ashanti region of Ghana, shows us his Mectizan®, which he has just had administered.

column74: Anecdotally, lots of the lifeboat rescues will be something relatively minor, like a fishing net getting stuck in a propellor, and only a few of them will be major incidents. Similarly with the lifeguard incidents on the beach, lots of them will be someone needing a plaster or a child getting lost (who quite likely would have been found anyway if the lifeguard hadn't been there) and only a few will be major.

column58: RNLI works to save lives at sea around the coasts of Britain and Ireland through its work with lifeguards, lifeboats, and flood rescue.
column60: On a cold February night, RNLI volunteers from Scarborough launched their lifeboat into dark and treacherous conditions. Led by Helm Rudi Barman, they braved breaking 2m waves and whipping force 7 winds to reach Andrew McGeown. They brought him to shore and did everything they could to revive him. Tragically, Andrew was beyond help. Rudi received the RNLI’s Bronze Medal for Gallantry for his leadership, boathandling skills and bravery. ‘I don’t think anything can ever prepare you for a rescue like that,’ he says. ‘It was the most difficult rescue I’ve been on. But it’s something we train for day in, day out. To be recognised with an award like this is a great honour, but it’s not just me. There are many different wheels that work in this station down to the people who have trained me and the crew over the years.’

A person is reached directly when he or she has received one or more project/programme inputs from Save the Children or a partner; or has participated in activities or accessed services provided by Save the Children, a partner, or institutions or individuals supported by Save the Children or its partners. A person is reached indirectly through information, education or communication and/or awareness raising efforts; or events conducted or supported by Save the Children or one of its implementing partners; or if a family or community member’s wellbeing is expected to be enhanced by a person reached directly by Save the Children or one of its partners.

column58: Save the Children works in over 100 countries to provide children with education, healthcare and disaster relief and protect their rights
column59: "Save the Children" is an independent organisation that targets marginalised and deprived children to help them "survive", "learn" and "be protected". Their major projects include those delivering protection, rights and education for vulnerable children. They aim at changing the world for children in need by means of innovative programs, bold campaigns, independent advocacy and high impact partnerships. They are a global movement consisting of 29 member countries and are operational in 120 countries. With guiding principles of accountability, ambition, collaboration, creativity and integrity, they envision that every child attains the right to survival, protection, development and participation. They intend to inspire breakthroughs in the way the world treats children and to achieve immediate and lasting change in their lives.

column46: Solar aid exited from two countries (Kenya and Tanzania) within the most recent financial year (2015-16). There were costs to this exit, which are reflected within the figures we use. SoGive judged that it would be overly pessimistic to calculate the cost per solar lamp based solely on the 2015-16 financial year, since this would essentially bake in an assumption that further exit costs will be incurred next year too, which we don't know to be true. However, under our understanding of Solar Aid's philosophy, they are happy for solar lamps to be adopted within a country, and they don't mind if this is via the success of local providers or whether it's Solar Aid's own company (Sunny Money) which takes lion's share of the market. Therefore we are calculating the cost per solar lamp based on the last 2 years: Apr 2014 - Mar 2016. This implicitly bakes in some chance that more costs may be incurred for leaving other countries.
column52: Reserves figure comes from p8. Still looks low to me, but they define their target as £225k, so not far off as per their judgement

column58: Turkish charity working to eliminate landmines
column68: I found out about this from The Funding Network (TFN). They don't seem to have a website or annual report; the best I could find was thier facebook page (in Turkish) and this article that TFN linked to http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/over-one-million-landmines-remain-undetected-in-turkey-ngo.aspx?pageID=238&nid=58713. This article is where the ratio comes from - it refers to the cost of clearing one mine, which it says is 4,678 TL (it's a Turkish article)
column74: Demining has huge amount of positive outcomes, including the benefits to those people who don't lose limbs, but also land is reclaimed and can be used for agriculture. Further research needed into impact of being injured by a mine - what proportion of the time does someone lose a limb? What proportion of the time does someone die? How many mines do you have to clear before the land is considered safe to reuse for agricultural or other purposes?

column74: Demining has huge amount of positive outcomes, including the benefits to those people who don't lose limbs, but also land is reclaimed and can be used for agriculture. Further research needed into impact of being injured by a mine - what proportion of the time does someone lose a limb? What proportion of the time does someone die? How many mines do you have to clear before the land is considered safe to reuse for agricultural or other purposes? In the case of MAG, need to adjust downwards because some (most, I suspect) of the beneficiaries are receiving risk education, which has a dilution effect (ie most recipients of risk education would not have been injured by a mine anyway, whether or not the risk education had happened). When questioning the charity about their figures, I received incoherent answers - this may just be because of the person answering the question, but it may also indicate that the content of the accounts is incoherent.

column67: I left a note in this spreadsheet saying I sent a query in mid-2015, however I didn't get a reply and I can't find a trace of the email, so maybe something went wrong and it didn't send. New query sent on 12th March 2016. I also asked about reserves. Update as at 5th May - I have been in touch with Matthew Jeffrey at World Vision, He has said that he will put me through to World Vision global (I think he is World Vision UK). This has taken almost 2 months, because he replies slowly. He also seems to have been confused about the federated nature of World Vision. For the questions about microfinance, he pointed me to the vision fund website, which seems to suggest a lack of transparency and unwillingness to talk about their microfinance work. Still no answer about how much reserves they have or the cost per ben ratio - he should be putting me in touch with someone at World Vision International who can hopefully help with this.

column20: The total spend figure is difficult to reconcile. On the charity commission website, it's given as £854,233,000, however the accounts show a total spend of £465m for the Grant-in-aid side of their work and £406.8m for the lottery side of their work, which sum to £872m, so I contacted the arts council and they explained that "The £854m figure is derived from total GIA expenditure (£465.1m) LESS Support costs relating to Lottery (£17.7m) PLUS total Lottery expenditure (£406.8m)". They didn't explain *why* to deduct the lottery support costs, but I'm assuming it's to avoid a double count. For the number of beneficiaries I was directed to a spreadsheet accessed from http://www.artscouncil.org.uk/funding/grants-arts/2015/grants-arts/awards-made-area-and-artform/; this showed 4,012 grants for the financial year 2014-15, however when I discussed the calcs further with the Arts Council, they seemed to think the correct number was more like 5800, presumably because that figure would include the lottery-funded grants as well (have sent a query, this is being confirmed)

column47: The 13.2 million relates to beneficiaries reached specifically through grant funded programs. There is a risk therefore that the costs we are using might be overegged (i.e. perhaps we are using a cost figure that relates to grants and Plan's own work, whereas the number of beneficiaries listed refers only to those who are funded via grants) The accounts indicate that 52.4 million are spent on grants out of the 59.5 million total expenditure. This means that even if the costs are inconsistent with the number of beneficiaries, the extent of the inconsistency is small.

Hence treated as income from charitable activities. There are other income items in the accounts which are labelled as income from charitable activities, which largely seem to be grants, so I have treated these as grants here (i.e. not treated as income from charitable activities in this database)

column2: Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals
column47: For the number of beneficiaries, I simply counted the 257m fish and animals reared under RSPCA welfare standards; there are in fact several other types of intervention, but the number of beneficiaries for the others is small enough that it is unlikely to materially impact anything. Whether or not it's appropriate to include these animals is debatable - to a certain extent you could argue that for many (most?) of the animals affected here, it could be that those who undertake these standards would in fact have chosen to treat the animals decently anyway, suggesting that for many of the 257 million animals, they are unaffected.  (although of course, the work done here is still of value)
column74: The difference in welfare between those animals reared under RSPCA welfare standards and those battery farms is huge

column20: P8: "We cared for over 650 people in our six care homes in England this year" // P9: "We have also supported over 400 injured, wounded or sick members of the Armed Forces through the Battle Back Centre at Lilleshall, providing adaptive sport and adventurous training as a means to recovery" // P9: "Our specialist health and welfare advisors have provided outreach services to over 1,100 vulnerable beneficiaries such as homeless veterans and prison leavers" // P9: "more than 18,500 people have been able to go on a much needed break"
column47: The number of direct beneficiaries is perhaps not complete, the report mentions the opening of several dropin centres, but no indication of the number of people who use these. A large proportion of the counted beneficiaries (18,500) are people getting a "much-needed break", with no indication of said beneficiaries having more need for a much-needed break than you or I do. The outreach services to over 1100 vulnerable beneficiaries such as homeless/prison leavers sounds useful, but only because they are working with those vulnerable groups, and another charity that focuses on the homeless or prison leavers could presumably do just as well. What's more, it would be bizarre for the outreach workers to go to a group of people and help some, but not others who are not vets.

column47: Interestingly, the accounts state that the surgery "can" cost as little as $250. However. taking the crude approach of total cost divided by number of beneficiaries indicates an average cost in excess of $1000. Admittedly, this cost includes other things such as supporting doctors overseas, providing training and writing free articles. It would be good to know a cost breakdown for this, but this level of info is not available in the annual report. Perhaps need to contact charity to get more info about this?
column74: The annual report describes movingly how the fate of a child can be changed by the surgery to address a cleft palate, since the child may be withdrawn or ostracised as a result of their disfigurement. However it gives no indication of how widespread this is; while I am confident that there are some cultures who would ostracise children with a cleft palate, I would speculate that a material proportion (maybe the majority?) of the children helped were in fact quite happy with their lives before the intervention, and that while the intervention would have been (presumably) viewed positively by the beneficiary and his/her family at the time, would likely have done little to improve their lives (note that this is pure speculation; the charity provides no evidence to confirm or deny this). The rating of 3 assumes that the surgery can on occasions be life-changingly positive, and in other cases would render the beneficiary's life not materially better - more evidence would be needed to justify a higher rating. Update: found some research here, which seems to suggest that it's moderately cost-effective: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20063097. There's also this study too: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22986629

column58: Smile Train works in countries around the world to tackle cleft lip and palate, mostly by providing surgeries for children, but also through training and education.
column60:
At six years old, Osawa Owiti already faced more than his fair share of hardships. Born in a remote village in Tanzania, he was the only child his fellow villagers had known to be born with a cleft. Even relatives treated Osawa differently. He became painfully shy and never laughed, so to not draw attention to his cleft lip.
His mother was also subject to tremendous criticism, unjustly blamed by her in-laws for Osawa’s cleft. The family of six, including his father and three siblings, persevered, remaining close despite the stigma surrounding Osawa.
Thanks to Smile Train donors and the skilled surgeons at Comprehensive Community Based Rehabilitation Hospital in Tanzania, Osawa received the life changing cleft surgery that he so desperately needed.
After the surgery Osawa’s mother stated, “My husband and I are forever grateful to Smile Train and its supporters for giving Osawa not just a new smile, but a fresh start at a life with opportunities.”

column47: 75% of the beneficiaries are dogs which have been microchipped, and 21% have been neutered, so only 4% have been rehomed, although this actually constitutes around half of the cost (£40m according to p9 of the 2014 accounts); if we were to just consider the 12,419 beneficiaries of the rehoming work
column74: Getting pets microchipped becomes valuable only when the pet is lost. According to "Frequency of Lost Dogs and Cats in the United States and the Methods Used to Locate Them" (www.mdpi.com/2076-2615/2/2/301/pdf) 15% of dogs are lost, and of those most are found by just searching the neighbourhood - only 14% of that 15% actually benefit from the microchip. In other words, only around 2% of those actually benefit from the chip, so that intervention gets a 1 out of 5 for its impactfulness. Neutering is also a valuable intervention because it stops the dog from breeding, which would be difficult to manage, however this is a qualified opinion, since according to http://www.yourpurebredpuppy.com/health/articles/neutering-male-dog.html , it can triple the risk of obesity, increase the risk of a cancer called hemangiosarcoma, triple the risk of hypothyroidism, increase the risk of geriatric cognitive impairment, and other risks. On balance it's still positive and gets a 4 out of 5. Caring for rehomed dogs is clearly 5 out of 5, since their condition without that care would be terrible.

column58: Islamic relief is an independent NGO that responds to disasters and emergencies and also promotes sustainable economic and social development by working with local communities – regardless of race, religion or gender.
column59: Islamic relief is a humanitarian agency that provides relief in the form of financial donations as well as direct work in all parts of the world. The organisation that started operating in 1984 first aimed at providing aid and assistance to relieve poverty and suffering worldwide, but later expanded its range of operations to enable sustainable development in various communities - by means of provision of water, food, shelter, health and education. They function in accordance to the Islamic principles of compassion, justice, custodianship, sincerity and excellence. Over the 30 years of their functioning, they currently have 40 offices in over 100 countres and continue their endeavour in learning and improving their work and serving the needy.

column74: While the meat is claimed to be, and no doubt is, of high quality, this is just one meal, handed out a specific time when there is a strong religiously motivated desire to give meat to the poor. Hence without funding this, there would likely be other donations of meat to the poor at this time - giving food (or better, cash) to the poor. Even if somehow a qurbani meat distribution did reach someone who would not have had access to qurbani meat from someone else, then they would probably not have received it at jsut the right time when they most need food. This certainly fails the give directly test (i.e. it would be better to give the money directly to the poor)

column60: After a traumatic separation from her husband, Brenda was forced to rent with her two daughters. What first seemed like a cottage in a dream location soon turned into a living nightmare. Tiles fell from the walls. Wallpaper peeled off from damp. The ceiling in the lounge collapsed. But when Brenda’s solicitor wrote to the landlord on her behalf, the response was an eviction notice. Brenda and her family had two months to leave. That’s when our adviser Kellie took up her case. The strong defence that Shelter put forward meant the judge halted the action, and Brenda had time to find somewhere safe for her family to live.

column20: Info about the number of beneficiaries reached is provided in the "Mission" section, where it states tha 600,000 beneficiaries receive food each month. Presumably it would be incorrect to take the annual number of beneficiairies as 600,000x12, since lots of those people would continue coming back from one month to the next. Instead I have taken the figure of 600,000 as the number of people being supported on an ongoing basis
column47: Many members of the leadership team work on a voluntary basis, which helps to control the cost base
column68: Top charity according to charity navigator
column74: The important question here is the counterfactual question - how would the beneficiaries eat if they did not receive food from the food bank? The midwest food bank website says that their beneficiaries aren't always below the poverty line "People living above the poverty line are often at risk of hunger as well" (http://www.midwestfoodbank.org/how-we-help/hunger-is-real). So if the food bank were not there, would beneficiaries in the midwest still be able to eat by rationalising some other expenditure? Some of the beneficiaries are in E Africa, and it's difficult to find any information about who in East Africa is a beneficiary, however I suspect they are more likely to suffer or go hungry if not provided with food. No information is provided about the split between the E African beneficiaries and the American beneficiaries, or why it would be better to provide the African beneficiaries with food rather than money.

column20: The 400,000 figure (phrased as "more than 400,000") comes from Goal C on P8
column47: The 400,000 figure (phrased as "more than 400,000") includes information, advice, therapy, advocacy and peer support - no breakdown provided as to how many people received which services. Other valuable outcomes (from Goals A,B,D,etc) include developing resilience, reducing stigma and others. Need to investigate the structure of the charity - could it be that there are further missing costs from local organisations?

column74: Therapy, and perhaps also advocacy and peer support, sound like potentially very strong and life changing interventions. Information and advice are also valuable, but not as life-changing. Difficult to give much of an opinion without a breakdown of how many people received each intervention.

column18: Source is essentially Sanjay's insider knowledge. it's complicated because the true cost is the c £10m of spend at the level of the central charity + the cost of each of the c 200 branches, whose overall spend sums to c another £10m - no easy way of calculating that latter figure (the hard way is to go through the financials of all 201 entities and add them up)
column23: Samaritans provides free, 24 hour, confidential emotional support for people who are experiencing feelings of distress, despair or suicidal thoughts.
column47: Strictly this is the cost per intervention, not cost per beneficiary (i.e. cost per contact/call with Samaritans, but it could be that the same person calls several times, so the cost per beneficiary is higher)
column58: Samaritans alleviates distress and despair by providing confidential emotional support, primarily through its phone helpline
column74: For any one beneficiary, the impactfulness is potentially high, the low score is to account for those for whom Samaritans' intervention is helpful, but not dramatic, and for the fact that the cost shown is the cost per call, not the cost per beneficiary - i.e. a typical call will often not make a huge impact, but going through with several calls may be hugely helpful

column47: Of the 997 wishes, 893 are wishes granted to a seriously ill child, and 104 are "wish assists". I'm not sure what that means, but I think it's when a child abroad wishes to visit the UK, and the UK entity helps make that happen. I have not included the 101 cases where preparations were started but the wish "sadly had to be cancelled" (presumably the child died?) Arguably this is not giving enough credit, since the family and child presumably benefitted from knowing that things were being done for them, even if they didn't get the actual wish in the end.

column47: No of beneficiaries had to be inferred from IRS forms. The 2014 form (https://cdn.givedirectly.org/8e3fb271b6b1342e598be7e277e13664/FY2014Form990.pdf) indicated that Give directly had reached 19,000 recipients since 2009, and the previous year's form (https://www.givedirectly.org/pdf/FY2013Form990.pdf) indicated that they had reached 5000 recipients, so I just subtracted one from the other
column74: High impact, especially taking account the fact that a few hundred dollars have a high purchasing power in the target country. More info in the study by Haushofer et al, Nov 2013 (https://www.princeton.edu/~joha/publications/Haushofer_Shapiro_UCT_2013.pdf). It shows that health and education impacts were not particularly positive, although the study was only over one year. While self-reported well-being seemed to increase, the less bias-prone measure of cortisol readings showed no obvious positive effect, possibly suggesting that the self-reported positive effects were overstated - there is after all an incentive for respondents to indicate positive results so that further transfers arrive. Given the clear benefits to food security and female empowerment, it seems clear that there are definite benefits.

column20: Just using the proportion of each donation that goes to the poor
column23: Cash is transferred directly to the poorest people of poor communities using mobile money tech. Give Directly is planning to conduct a trial of Universal Basic Income
column46: The standard SoGive approach of allocating the number of beneficiaries to the cost of delivering the work doesn't work so well for Give Directly, partly because the amount given to each beneficiary is not a constant. Instead we use the proportion that reaches the end beneficiary, which we source from the Give Directly website

column58: GiveDirectly allows donors to send money directly to the poor with no strings attached. High quality research suggests this money is largely spent on capital investment such as housing/land and livestock.
column60:
What did you spend your first transfer on?
I used my second transfer to buy a plot of land since i was staying with my brother and also wanted to be independent. I also bought a cow and a goat
Describe the biggest difference in your daily life.
The biggest difference in my daily life was getting land where I can construct a house for myself 
What did you spend your first transfer on?
I spent my first transfer on buying households like a bed ,mattress bedsheets, goat and gave out some little money to book for a land.
Describe the moment when you received your money. How did you feel?
I felt happy when I received my money.i saw my life being successful since i was in a poor situation and had no hope of improving my situation.

column23: An obstetric fistula is a hole between the vagina and rectum or bladder that is caused by prolonged obstructed labor, leaving a woman incontinent of urine or feces or both.
column58: Obstetric fistula is a preventable childbirth injury that devastates the lives of mothers. Fistula Foundation funds fistula treatment in Africa and Asia.
column60: Annet Jane was only 14 when she became pregnant with her first and only child. Her water broke at night, and she planned to labour at home until the next morning, when she and her husband would borrow a bicycle for the 18-mile trip to the nearest hospital. Tragically, she lost the baby. The prolonged labour also left her with a fistula (a hole between the vagina and rectum or bladder). Twenty-three years later, through a fistula clinic at our partner clinic at Fistula Foundation's partner site CoRSU Rehabilitation Hospital in Uganda, Annet Jane was finally able to receive treatment. "I am happy that for the first time in my life I am completely dry," she says. "I can freely speak in public without anyone belittling me."

column23: Medicinema holds film screenings for sick children in hospital.
column25: patient(s) and their families (singular: family) enabled to watch films free of charge
column58: MediCinema exists to bring the joy and escapism of cinema to patients undergoing treatment for complex illnesses and injuries around the UK
column74: While not hugely expensive, it's also quite a bit more expensive than an ordinary cinema ticket. Arguably that's worth it given that bedridden children in hospital won't get access to the cinema otherwise, and they are getting a much better experience than they would get from an ordinary cinema. Ultimately though, the opportunity to have a positive cinema experience, while a good thing, is not obviously a top giving opportunity given how much more life-changing things can be done for cheaper. Also it appeals to a number of moneyed people in the cinema industry, meaning that it already gets a lot of support from people who are biased towards the intervention, and less likely to assess it on its merits and take into account the full impact

column47: it's not entirely clear - it refers to "some 300 families", so I don't know whether the total number of beneficiaries is actually higher than that. The information on the Raise Your Hands website suggests that it's grown now to more like 500 (https://raiseyourhands.org.uk/charities/grief-encounter/), but I'm sticking to the number in the annual report to achieve consistency in the ratio
column74: Distinct lack of information about impact. Founded by someone who suffered from bereavement as a child and apparently with the requisite skills and background, and focusing on a target group with a clear need, I'm inclined to think that the quality of this intervention is probably very good, although it would likely be better if the management team thought about what they are trying to achieve better (worse, if they are thinking about this properly, they are not reporting it, in which case they are almost certainly performing poorly) It is also important to remember that bereavement is a complex process, especially within this young demographic; so we should expect to see several beneficiaries who are still suffering after working with this charity

column74: Based on my experience, it seems to provide highly relevant education in contexts where education would otherwise be skipped. Part of the value comes the relevance of the education provided as well. However more info would be needed to determine this

column20: I was surprised that this was the most recent set of accounts, but it seems that Educaid switched from being a charity & company ltd by guarantee to being a CIO, and in the switch from one entity to another, one set of accounts was dropped. column47: The 3000-odd beneficiaries counted here include c 700 or so that are in schools managed with "Make it Happen" (a partner organisation) - so the most appropriate ratio would include the relevant costs from make it happen in the numerator. The TFN application said that £5000 would pay for 240 girls to go to school - not sure how this fits in with this (it seems to be inconsistent)
column68: Volunteered with them in 2011 (introduction from AfID - Accounting for Int development)
column74: Strong quality of intervention - without Educaid I have seen that the quality of education in Sierra Leone is weak (unless you are rich, but Educaid only works with children from impoverished families). Counterfactual - as Educaid is the only free secondary school in SL, there is likely to be no way for these children to get access to education otherwise. Furthermore, the quality of education is good.

column47: 51 trainees is mentioned on p7. Could argue that this should just be the 36 trainees who "fully engaged" with the programme mentioned on p4
column58: Switchback is a charity which provides an intensive rehabilitation programme for ex-offenders
column74: The annual report points out that they select inmates who want to live differently on release and are willing to commit. It then goes on to compare the 14% recidivism rate among its beneficiaries with the 58% recidivism rate among the wider population of those who have left prison in the same age group, apparently without realising that they had benefit of starting with a biased sample. I can't say for sure what the recidivism rate would be among the target group if they hadn't received switchback's mentoring, but I suspect it would be substantially lower than 58%, since the personal motivation to succeed must count for a lot.

column23: Sport 4 Life UK helps create a better future for young people aged 12 to 25 by improving their employability and key life skills, through our sports-themed personal development programmes
column25: youth(s) attending (but not necessarily meaningfully engaging in) sport-themed personal development, educational, or employability programmes
column47: 777 beneficiaries comes from http://sport4life.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/S4LAnnualReport-2013-14_000.pdf
column58: Sport 4 life changes the lives of Birmingham's most disadvantaged young people through the power of sport
column74: Using a link between sport and educational programmes seems like an effective way to engage with hard to reach young people. It's very hard to gauge the impact of their work based on the info they provide. The website includes many nice stats (77% progressed out of NEET status, 92% of ex-offenders did not reoffend, 92% of people reported an increase in self esteem) However it's hard to discern anything meaningful from this because there's no counterfactual (i.e. how many people would have progressed out of NEET status anyway? how many would have improved their self-esteem as they got older anyway? etc) On balance I would guess that sport4life is probably doing quite well and can probably take the credit for much of the improvement they note. More info needed: how do they select their beneficiaries, and the counterfactuals

column23: pupils in London schools receiving talks about teenage pregnancy from people who themselves have been teen parents
column25: youth(s) who became parents as teenagers provided with employment
column58: UK charity hiring teen parents to raise the awareness of problems with teen pregnancy
column74: The way they operate seems good, using a peer education model that seems promising. The use of teenage mothers as staff members also sounds like a strength of the model. The key question is the importance of the cause. I could find little information in the annual report to answer this question. I have tried looking for research to help understand the answer to this, and I can find many journal articles which baldly state/assume that teenage pregnancy is bad, but little to estimate how bad, or high how a priority it should be. When considering the overall assessment of the charity, it will be important to remember that the cost per beneficiary will appear low (around £40 at the moment) because it will reach lots of people, but most of them would not have become teenage parents anyway. The low impactfulness assessment largley also reflects the fact that most of the people in the audience would not have been involved in teenage pregnancy anyway, and hence will come away unaffected

column25: prisoner(s) and their families (singular: family) beniftted
column46: Storybook Dads themselves have calculated a cost of £29.45 per prisoner, however the figures are calculated from the numbers in the same report, it comes to something just over £30
column47: There is also the figure 17700 of beneficiaries reached, which we assumed the the combined number of prisoners and their families
column58: Storybook Dads helps maintain the vital emotional bond between parent and child by enabling parents to make bedtime story CDs, DVDs and other educational gifts for their children
column74: The annual report states that "Prisoners that keep in contact with their families are up to 6 times less likely to re-offend" - this seems incredibly powerful on its own, even ignoring the benefit to the children and families. It would be important to chase up the source of the statistic to see whether the background to the calculation applies in a relevant way to Storybook dads. Gut feel without having seen the original source of the stat is that the effect is probably not a 6-fold improvement in recidivism rates; rather I think that those who are more dedicated to the idea of engaging with Storybook Dads are more likely to be dedicated to not reoffending when they get out. The rating of 3 out of 5 is based on the idea that maintaining a connection with the family can have a positive effect, albeit not a sixfold improvement (as well as the other benefits of the programme, of course). The info at http://www.researchgate.net/publication/269700976_Case_Study_Storybook_Dads seems positive as well. It left me somewhat confused about the reference to profitability though, how does that work? I'm also surprised that the charity can offer the service so cost-effectively - I say this partly because I would have thought that the recordings would need to be checked for the risk that the inmates smuggle out secret messages, and hence the recordings would need to be checked. I have seen no sign of this in the info I've read though.

column46: The cost per beneficiary is based on info from the funding network (http://www.thefundingnetwork.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/All-Summaries1.pdf) - £5000 pays for 240 children, however this is just one project (Min el Bahar) so might not be representative of the whole organisation
column68: TFN - can also see info at http://www.thefundingnetwork.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/All-Summaries1.pdf
column74: There are some positives here; the charity itself argues that the opportunity to have a day out to see the seaside is intrinsically a benefit, which is true. However this is not a dramatic benefit. The valuable intangible benefit may be building up trust and relationships between Israelis and Palestinians, however since the trips only occur once a year, the contact is infrequent enough that no real friendships are likely to occur, and this impact will be slight.

column47: Number of beneficiaries given towards the end of p2. May be somewhat inflated as the charity is still fairly new, although I think coaching is fundamentally quite pricey. Furthermore, I believe that the coachees are just those who are most willing and engaged, which means that they may have been quite likely to avoid recidivism themselves anyway
column58: Charity for the rehabilitation of young offenders through professional coaching that tackle violence, improve the prison environment and reduce reoffending
column74: One study based on 8 subjects seemed to show a huge improvement in recidivism rates. However the study did not factor in the possibility that there is a self-selecting bias in participants (i.e. that the people who opt to do the coaching are those who are already most motivated to improve their lives) Hence if Spark Inside were not there, they would likely have taken up other opportunities instead, or failing that would have been more motivated than average to end their criminal behaviour anyway. Spark Inside no doubt does do good work to help this process, but I don't think it makes sense to compare the Spark Inside recidivism rates with the general reoffending rates.

column47: Y/E 31 MARCH 2014 accounts: P3 "66 young people completed or gained certificates in: <...>" - we don't know if this is the full list of beneficiaries though.
column74: At first glance this seems like an intervention driven by the founders' interests, and not by the needs of the beneficiaries (why is it a good thing for young people to be engaged in motorcycle or indeed the motor industry more generally, as opposed to, say medical/health issues? or the media? Or any other area of interest that could lead to employment?) A better insight could come from knowing more about how they select children to participate. The info from Raise your Hands seems to suggest that they do manage to reach children from deprived backgrounds (see https://raiseyourhands.org.uk/news/raise-your-hands-visits-sparkplug/) However their write-up may perhaps overstate the situation - for example I suspect it's an exaggeration to suggest that Sparkplug is often a child's primary carer. There is also little indication of the actual change they achieve. The intervention aims to reduce crime and anti-social behaviour, but there seems to be no reporting on whether this has happened at all; in the absence of any other information, my guess would be that the impact is slight - I would guess that some people have benefited from have decent role models and access to qualifications, but that these people were probably in the right place (psychologically) to make the most of the opportunities available and would have found something else anyway. Gut feel - this is not transformative.

column74: Seems promising, and access to safe water is clearly a highly impactful intervention for people who otherwise would have none. The hygiene area is interesting, as it appears very cheap. It is not clear how impactful it is (i.e. of the people who are on the receiving end of health promition, what proportion actually end up changing behaviour in a sustained way?) The 2012 hygiene framework sounds promising in this regard, but doesn't provide any data on actual results achieved, only on the methodology. The closest it gets to actual results are not WaterAid's own actual results, but rather it quotes the World Bank / WHO Disease control priorities project which gives a very impressive cost effectiveness estimate for this intervention. However GWWC argue that the studies underlying this are not robust (https://www.givingwhatwecan.org/research/other-causes/water-sanitation-and-hygiene-wash/)

column74: It's hard to say what the rating for this should be, since although the "hidden hunger" of micronutrient deficiency *can* lead to preventable blindness, increased rates of miscarriage, maternal death during childbirth, birth defects, compromised immune systems, and cognitive and developmental delays, it's not at all clear how often this happens. However PHC's website states that "THE COPENHAGEN CONSENSUS ESTIMATES THAT EVERY $1 SPENT ON FORTIFICATION RESULTS IN $9 IN BENEFITS TO THE ECONOMY." (http://projecthealthychildren.org/why-food-fortification/fortification-overview/) This presumably means that the downsides of micronutrient deficiency are not that rare, and hence the impact is at least moderately high. However the Copenhagen Consensus info that I've just referred to was actually taking into account the cost per beneficiary, and the whole point of this metric is to look at the impactfulness without factoring in cost.

column46: SoGive figure for cost per tablet distributed agrees with Givewell, and disagrees with SCI - SCI claims it costs £1 to cover 3 people, Givewell argues it costs $1.19 (or £0.76). The difference is because of the cost of the drugs and the government support. The drugs are donated by the drugs firm and have value for them. Hence if the drugs company stopped donating the drugs, someone would have to donate money to make up for the fact that the drugs company doesn't donate. Similarly for the government support, we consider this to be an input that has been donated by the government.

However he then stated this was not the final version and asked me not to use them. I have not requested a more up to date version since.
column58: Schistosomiasis Control Initiative (SCI) has a cost-effective scalable programme to treat people (mostly children) suffering from Schistosomiasis (otherwise known as Bilharzia) and other worm diseases in several countries, mostly in Africa
column60: Schistosomiasis (or Bilharzia) is a parasitic disease that blights the lives of millions. The Schistosomiasis control initiative uses a cost-effective school-based method to distribute cheap treatments to millions of people - mostly children. Apart from the health benefits of not suffering from a parasitic infection of the gut, treatment for Schistosomiasis also makes its beneficiaries significantly (c 20%) richer in later life
column67: Multiple meetings and discussions
column74: Difficult to say how impactful the intervention is - analysis from Givewell seems to suggest the health impact is small; however Alan Fenwick disputes this (although he is clearly conflicted). Research indicates that deworming is a cost-effective way of getting children into school, although test scores don't appear to improve much. Research also suggests that earnings improve significantly when the child grows up. I haven't seen anything to say whether the jobs that dewormed children have are maybe jobs that woudl have gone to someone else anyway, perhaps indicating that the net good done is not substantial

column23: National Trust sites often have an entry fee. However donations help to subsidise those visits to make them more affordable. On average, we show here how many of those visitors you have subsidised. The entry fees collectively constitute around 30% of the cost of running the Trust, based on the most recent info reviewed by SoGive
column47: As the aim of the charity is to preserve land, one could argue that the beneficiary is the land, not the people who visit it. However, I've taken the view that land is not sentient, and therefore it doesn't matter whether the land is cared for unless the land being cared for somehow impacts on the lives of someone. Arguably this should include the animals on that land, however animal welfare is not a stated aim of the Trust, and as far as I can tell, there is relatively little sign that this is the main focus of their work. Besides, there is no data available on this (not that I have asked the Trust about this). Income generated from charitable activities has been excluded, which includes entrance fees, parking fees, revenue generated from the likes of on-site coffee shops and membership fees. Membership fees confer benefits such as free entrance to sites, so it makes sense to treat this as part of the income from charitable activities.
column52: Confusing. P19 states: "our unrestricted reserves amount to £234.5 million", however the amount shown on the chart on the following page, or indeed on the balance sheet or note 16 don't seemt o agree to this. The reserves are above their target of £164m - they don't appear to have considered what would count as "too much". My gut feel says that the reserves amount seems high, however they do have justifications for such a high number on p19, although I don't find those reasons very compelling
column53: You have allowed XXX people to have subsidised entry to national trust destinations
column58: UK conservation charity, protecting historic buildings, monuments, remains and green spaces, bequeathed to the Trust to keep open to the public
column60: Sandham Memorial Chapel in the village of Burghclere, Hampshire, is a Grade I listed 1920s decorated chapel built to accommodate a series of paintings by Stanley Spencer, inspired by his experiences during the First World War. In 2013, with the support of the Heritage Lottery Fund, the Wolfson Foundation and many other funding partners, we began a project to make conservation improvements and to enhance the visitor experience. Two alms-houses flanking the Chapel were transformed into new interpretation spaces, a new visitor reception and improved staff and volunteer facilities were opened, while a ‘reflective garden’ was created at the back of the Chapel. Access for all visitors to the Chapel was improved and visitor facilities added. The Chapel reopened to the public on Monday 5 August 2014 to coincide with the Great War centenary.
column65: The beautiful wildflower meadow at Sandham Memorial Chapel
column74: According to the description on the charity commission website, the activities of the charity are to "LOOK AFTER PLACES OF HISTORIC INTEREST OR NATURAL BEAUTY". The counterfactual here is that if the National Trust didn't look after these, someone else would own these pieces of land, and they might not look after them properly or make them available to the public. But they also might. Indeed some might argue that someone who has paid a lot of money to personally own land is actually more likely to take proper care of it than employees of the National Trust, however I have erred on the side of assuming that the National Trust has special expertise and is therefore better able to take care of its properties than a private owner. This is not enough to move the overall impactfulness score above the 1 level though, since this is fundamentally a nice day, and not something lifechanging.

column1: Royal National Institute of Blind People (RNIB)
column20: page 1 refers to advice services for 60000 people
column55: No, need to review. This was done ages ago, and need to redo, using more up to date figures, and properly taking into account the project splits
column74: RNIB does many positive things around providing advice to blind/visually impaired people to help them make the most of their lives. The information/support/advice element of their work is suggestive of a 2 out of 5 rating, since it is good, but not transformative. I would adjust it up to a 2.5 because the 60,000 beneficiaries counted do not account for all the services - e.g. 20,000 talking books were made available. A material proportion of their income (40%) is income that is generated by charitable activities, which presumably means that for some of their activities some people will be excluded because they don't have enough money (v hard to be sure of this though, I struggled to find more information about this income when I looked at the annual report) This would count somewhat negatively towards the overall assessment.

column47: Quote from page 22 follows. Sadly while we have some impact info, it's not on a consistent basis with the financials.  "• This year, our Helpline answered 213,000 calls and 35,185 letters and emails. We’ve worked hard to improve our customer satisfaction by reducing caller waiting time: 87 per cent of calls are answered in 20 seconds. • This year, 96,000 people with sight loss used our direct services. This included 36,500 new people. The overall figure has remained static since last year and was under target by 26,000 people. • People rely on our confidential counselling service when they reach breaking point: this year, our sight loss counselling team received 1,395 referrals. This is 17 per cent more than last year. We have supported 15,300 people with our benefits advice service, exceeding our target by 31 per cent and achieving growth of 24 per cent compared to last year. We identified £19.5million in unclaimed benefits; £2.9million more than last year."

Somewhat surprisingly, the trustees have set a target of only £7.7m of reserves, which is only around 10% of the total annual spend. column58: VSO offers volunteers the chance to work abroad to fight poverty in the developing world
column60: Education volunteer, Fred van den Brug, is supporting a project that uses technology to tackle some of Malawi's biggest education problems. Fred explains: Take teaching Mathematics. Lots of teaching is done ‘outside under a tree’, since there are not sufficient classrooms. It is quite common for the teacher to write an exercise on the chalkboard and children try to work out the solution and write it down in their exercise book...And then the waiting starts.“The children line up to show their results to the teacher, which takes an incredibly long time. The teacher checks all results one by one, which means it might take up to half an hour just to check if each child has written down the right answer. Fred is working on a project called 'Unlocking Talent Through Technology,' in which iPads are being used to give children direct feedback on their learning. The ‘digital teacher’ immediately responds on any result that the child has found for his/her exercise. The project is currently reaching almost 25,000 children, and now has funding to roll out further and reach 55,000 children.
column65: Alex Kachigamba shows off his certificate on his tablet after he successfully completed a lesson during the Unlocking Talent Through Technology class session at Biwi Primary School in Lilongwe.

column58: Médecins Sans Frontières provides assistance to populations in distress, to victims of natural or man-made disasters and to victims of armed conflict. They do so irrespective of race, religion, creed or political convictions.
column59:
Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is an international, independent, medical humanitarian organisation that delivers emergency aid to people affected by armed conflict, epidemics, natural disasters and exclusion from healthcare.  MSF offers assistance to people based on need, irrespective of race, religion, gender or political affiliation. 

MSF rejects the idea that poor people deserve third-rate medical care and strives to provide high-quality care to patients.  

Today, MSF is a worldwide movement of 21 sections, 24 associations and various other offices. They are bound together by MSF International, based in Geneva, Switzerland, which provides coordination, information and support to the MSF Movement.

column47: The annual report and accounts also refers to 640,000 people who heard opera on BBC radio 3. I have not included these in the calculation. The logic for saying that the opera-goers are beneficiaries is that they would not have been able to see the opera live at the ENO without the subsidy that comes from the charitable donations. However for the opera on the radio, listeners do still have the opportunity to listen to the opera on the radio, even if the ENO had not done this work. Admittedly, they might not have gotten to hear that particular production of that particular opera, but this starts to seem like splitting hairs.
column57: ENO has outputs other than people seeing its performances live at the Coliseum. For example they also do stuff on the radio or cinema screenings. This costing has assumed that the cost of getting performances viewed on the cinema or braodcast on the radio is relatively low, but we dn't have data on that, and if that's not the case then this would be a misleading costing

column15: • THE GENERAL PUBLIC / MANKIND
column16: • PROVIDES SERVICES
column20: No of nets/beneficiaries is visbile on p5, although this is just the number distributed. For a basis consistent with the amount spent, we need the number bought, which comes from note 5, p21 of the accounts. Impact 2 (people protected) is calculated based on the ratios implicit on page 5.
column25: people (singular: person) protected from malaria
column46: We have departed from the standard approach for calculating cost per output because we want to include the costs of working with partner organisations which are not captured within the accounts for AMF. Also, the accounts don't cost in the time for the CEO - Rob Mather - who doesn't take a salary. These costs are accounted for in the calculations conducted by GiveWell (which includes a notional salary of $100,000), so we have taken the number from GiveWell.
column47: Accounts state that 2,368,700 nets protects 4.3million people (p5), presumably because of people sharing a bed. They say that 100% of the funds donated go to bed nets. I don't think this gives the true picture; I think GiveWell has a figure of $5, which I think includes an allocation of costs from partner organisations (mostly Concern, I think) which is the more correct way of accounting for the costs. // In this case, AMF is growing quickly, so I'm allocating overheads from a smaller sized version of AMF to a large amount of nets. This is allocating too small an amount of overheads. So I'm using Givewell's figure here. Givewell gives the costs as "$4.35 in Malawi, roughly $5.92 in DRC, and roughly $5.14 in Ghana", so I've taken the median value here.
column52: Looks a bit high at first glance. AMF will be able to find ways to use this money (there are plenty more people needing mosquito nets)
column57: AMF provides a high level of detail and transparency about the malaria nets distributed.
column58: Against Malaria Foundation (AMF) enables distributions of long-lasting insecticide-treated bed nets (for protection against malaria) in developing countries.
column60: The WHO estimates that malaria affects 212 million people and kills over 400,000 people a year. Bed nets are an effective prevention mechanism
column74: Low rating because so many nets will protect people who otherwise would not in any case have become ill anyway (dilution effect)

column47: In addition to the 43,000 people included in the ratio calculated here, there were a further 35,721 carers helped, as well as 144,349 family members. It was not clear whether the family members received direct interventions specifically for them, or whether the benefits to them are judged to have accrued simply because work was done for the depressed/mentally suffering individual. For this reason, those individuals have received zero credit in this analysis. Furthermore, Basic Needs does influencing work as well, and the ratio (unfairly) includes the costs of this in there as well.
column74: Quality of work seems high, with 75% of beneficiaries reporting an improvement in symptoms. Basic Needs works on capacity building with local ministries of health, which seems like a cost-effective approach. Beneficiary participation seems high

column59:
Scope exists to make the UK a place where disabled people have the same opportunities as everyone else. Until then, we’ll be here. We provide support, information and advice to more than a quarter of a million disabled people and their families every year. We raise awareness of the issues that matter. And with your support, we'll keep driving change across society until this country is great for everyone.
Read more at https://www.scope.org.uk/About-Us/What-We-Do#S1rZD1FtYAYsEZpK.99

Scope claim their influencing efforts resulted in the Government’s commitment to halving the disability employment gap by 2020, and that they played a leading role in stopping the proposed cuts to Personal Independence Payments (PIP)

column52: The accounts give a different figure for the reserves - they state £1.6m. This is because (p13 of accounts) the Refugee Council counts includes £423k for money from the Guardian Christmas appeal which is "expected to be allocated in the next financial year" - this does not count as a true designation, it's simply reserves which can be spent next year, and it suggests that the need for funds in the Refugee Council is not that great. The other item is the £180k for potential future redundancies - this would be a valid designation if they were planned redundancies, but they're not. I thought perhaps this might be justified given that they have a £1.4m pension scheme, however the reserves section of the accounts mentions that the risk around the pension scheme has been removed, so that doesn't make sense.

column47: P3 of the annual report says "We worked with 17,250 households, approximately 120,000 people, in developing sustainable farming households. Of these, 7,653 households began their training programme, with 1,620 households graduated." I have ignored the figure about the people "worked with" who didn't start the training programme, but have assumed that those who started the training programme will have got some benefit out of it, and therefore there should be some credit for that. The 1620 households are the ones for whom there is the most benefit. Bizarrely the cost doesn't seem to have been given as a separate line item, so I had to add up the fundraising costs, the costs of charitable activities and governance costs. Note that some of the costs go on other capmaigning costs and other activities, which haven't been given relevant credit here.
column67: Email sent on 22/feb/16
column74: A video at https://www.sendacow.org/how-we-work shows that before their work, 23% of respondents were confident of being able to provide for their families, with 97% saying that they were confident after doing the training. Not clear how to reconcile this with the fact that only around 20% of those doing the course then "graduate" - I'm inclined to disregard the study shown in the video, as it seems likely that the respondents are biased to respond positively. And what's more, confidence doesn't really mean anything - the important question is whether they actually got a higher income at the end of it. I think the most important question is how big an impact does it make for he 1620 households who "graduate" - do they see a big increase in income? I'm going to guess yes.However the dilution effect means that the overall impact can't be too high - c 20% of the 7,653 beneficiaries will have a (presumably) big improvement lives, others a bit of help, and others minimal impact. Averaging this out to an impact of 3 seems right. More info may arrive, which may change this assessment. Note that a comparison with Bees For Development seems to suggest that BfD is much better, with a lower cost per beneficiary, and without any of the complications that arrive from giving goods to beneficiaries.

column18: Cost comes direct from the charity
column46: Cost of providing one beneficiary with training in beekeeping was provided directly by the charity. We have not been able to verify that the calculation method is consistent with the method used with other charities.
column47: Note that there is a risk of inconsistency in approach here, since I have taken the cost per ben from the charity and not from the accoutns. One difference is taht the other charities will have (an unfair) loading from other activities that don't have direct beneficiaries, and BfD does have those activities, but won't receive an unfair loading from them. Note also that the most recent (2014-15) accounts are not available at the time of writing, and the older accounts don't really cover the beekeeping training in order to reduce poverty work
column57: Cost per ben taken from charity, with no ability to cross reference to the accounts
column74: BfD estimates that 70% of participants successfully engage with the programme, and generate a significant amount of extra income for themselves as a result. 5% of participants are very successful, and become very rich from it, and the rest are not so successful, perhaps dropping out.
Not a lot of info about the effectiveness of the help, but I'm just scoring this to be hte same as Send A Cow, since their approach seems similar

column23: Our interpretation of the accounts suggests that most of the cost is covered by the elderly people or their family, so donations here are just subsidising that cost. MHA's care homes offer en-suite accommodation, home-cooked meals, individual support and personal care (such as bathing, dressing and administering medication when required) or nursing care provided by qualified nurses. Some offer specialist care, which may include specialist nursing, for people with dementia.

column20: The UK accounts contain some useful figures on P6: http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Accounts/Ends17/0001087417_AC_20141231_E_C.pdf
column47: Number of beneficiaries (or rather "clients") on groupwide basis is 228,751 annual clients (or 3.98...million cumulative clients). Uk accounts show 1,082,125 clients; this is because they apply a multiplier to convert individuals helped into households helped (source: email from Blair Diversi, interim CEO of iDE UK, 11/may/2016). The UK accounts state that the average annual income increase was £130, and this £130 was 11 times the amount invested, which suggests that the cost per beneficiary should come to around £11.8. If we divide the total groupwide cost of $22m (£14.4m) by the 1,082,125 individual beneficiaries you get £13 (which is close to £11.8). For this, I'm using the 228,751 clients, which makes the cost look a bit higher than that.

SWEDOW - this charity sends unwanted books from the UK to Africa. Unfortunately, this has little sign of efficacy; this RCT (http://www.nber.org/papers/w13300.pdf) indicates that all but the most talented students don't benefit from receiving textbooks because they don't speak good English. This study was done in rural Kenya. This charity operates in Lesotho, Malawi, S Africa and Tanzania. Would the children in those countries be more likely to speak better English?

column20: The email from Pratham indicated that the split of the costs is: Educational programs - 47% (Read India- 29%, urban programs 9%, Second Chance program 4%) Best to present all programs under the education umbrella. Vocational Training- 23%; ASER-9%; Digital Initiatives- 7%. The remaining 14% comprises of some small programs, central and state level cost plus other support functions.  I asked them about the remaining 14%, and they indicated that "State can central level cost is approximately 6% and some smaller programs plus support functions account for the remaining 8%." from which I infer that the 6% is entirely core costs / overheads and the 8% is mostly overheads, so I'm treating the 14% as entirely composed of overheads.

column23: The Philanthropy Workshop educates philanthropists in the frameworks, skills and methods for strategic philanthropy, and graduates form part of a network.
column47: The accounts state that the three week workshop is the primary activity of the charity, and that 12 philanthropists underwent this. I tried looking at note 6 of the accounts which provides more information about the programme spend, but the breakdown provided simply restated the total amount of programme spend, so there was no further information, so I couldn't check that the figures aligned with this claim. Income from charitable expenditure was zero this year, but was c £100k the previous year; I couldn't find any explanation about why this was, I'm guessing it's because they used to charge for the course, and then decided not to
column52: Reserves stated on p5 of accounts. Amount is high - all the trustees have to say baout it is that they believe it to be in line with their policy
column58: The Philanthropy Workshop provides strategic philanthropy education and networking.
column74: Intrinsic impact of educating philanthropists is potentially high. However it is confusing that the charity itself has a high level of reserves, and is still accepting donations, and even spending money in an attempt to gain more donations. The accounts claim that the trustees believe that this level of reserves is appropriate; how can this be credible given that there is no argument about a duty of care to beneficiaries, and I'm not aware of an unusually volatile level of funding for this charity. Does this mean that when educating philanthropists, they don't teach them about the possibility that the charity they are donating to might be too rich already? Or do they teach that, but not practice what they preach? An otherwise high rating has been marked down because of this concern

column47: The accounts mention non-cash contributions in the revenue section (mostly medical supplies) - it's not clear from the accounts whether the spend is purely cash spend, or whether it includes the expenditure of non-cash resources. If so, to establish whether this should be counted within the costs, we should work out how much of an opportunity cost it is for the donor - i.e. would the provider of those medical supplies have otherwise been able to sell those supplies profitably? If so, then they should be included as part of the cost, but if they were supplies that otherwise would have gone to waste, then they should not be included in the cost (although presumably in that case they shouldn't be used at all, I would have thought) This would alter the ratio by about 10-15%, which is not material enough to worry about. Income from charitable activities assumed to be zero, although I couldn't find anything to say this explicitly. However the model focuses on poor people in remote communities, so I'm guessing they're not charged

column58: Over one billion people globally lack access to healthcare because they live too far from a doctor or clinic. Last Mile Health ensures access to quality primary health care by training community health workers
column60: Over one billion people worldwide lack access to healthcare because they live too far from a health facility (World Health Organization, 2010). This problem is particularly acute in remote Liberia, where people living in communities furthest from the reach of the health system must walk for hours and across great distances to reach the nearest clinic. The impact of lack of access to care on health outcomes can be devastating: Liberia has among the highest maternal and child mortality rates in the world. Professionalized Community Health Workers (CHWs) are uniquely positioned to overcome this access gap. As the first point of contact to the health system, CHWs are trained to meet their community’s specific health needs while simultaneously serving as a critical link between the community and the broader health system

column47: It is unclear if their 'solar suitcase' is actually providing a huge benefit to the beneficiaries and further who these beneficiaries are. For example, the solar suitcase provides light during childbirth. How necessary is this, and how are they measuring their beneficiaries with the 'light provided'? In the instance where someone gives birth during the day, the light provided is not needed, is this still a beneficiary?
column53: You've provided XXXX safe births.
column57: Self audited. Data is not terribly comprhensive or detailed.
column58: We Care Solar promotes safe childbirth in developing countries using "Solar suitcases"
column60: "For everything you do, you need light" explained Ugandan midwife Esther Madudu. "You need to wash, clean and disinfect ... and there's no light. You postpone what you're doing. If you have a cervical tear, you must postpone until tomorrow. It is so painful to postpone the procedure until tomorrow." Without reliable electricity, midwives struggle to provide life-saving care by kerosene lanterns and flashlights. Doctors rush to finish emergency c/sections before they lose power. Health providers live in fear of nighttime deliveries, knowing they may not be able to treat complications if the sun is down"
column65: Candles light a labour and delivery room in a Ugandan health centre
column74: There is not enough data to be able to actually measure the quality of the intervention. My biggest concern is that there is no need for this product in the market. They are attempting to provide power during birth. I would suspect that they may distribute this product and that it may not be used after it is distributed. Further, I would say that there are more effective ways to enable hospitals to receive power. I think it would make a lot more sense to fund infrastructure programs, which would be better for the overall development of the nation and eventually lead to building of power.
