No - The granuality of financial information is far too high to reconcile with any of the impact data in the trustees report. Moreover, project-specific impact data is very limited in a large number of the projects mentioned - mostly focused on donation amounts and casuality figures in particular disasters, rather than their specific outputs.

The ovrerall scale of the charity is likely a key reason for this. 

Project-level analysis may be possible if UNICEF were willing to release the data. It should be noted they have an evaluation report database to hand which may be worth further analysis.

https://www.unicef.org/evaldatabase/index_13510.html

column47: Accounts show the income from charitable activities as £560k. At least some of that must from grants by the pigeon-hole principle (i.e. the total amount of income from charitable activities + the total amount of income from grants is more than the total income). I'm going to assume therefore that the £245.6k of funds from grants is entirely accounted for as income from charitable activity, and that the rest is genuine income from charitable activities

Comments and information about impact (even at outputs level) is poor. Could reasonably argue that the accounts say that the charity has zero impact, because the SOFA states (p11) that the expenditure is around two thirds fundraising costs and one third governance expenses, and zero on charitable activities. In reality, this is probably just poor accounting practice, since pages 20-21 seem to indicate that a material sum has been spent on guest speakers/preachers, radio/tv ministry and volunteer expenses. No mention was made of the sale of olive oil, however, nor of the 10 year battle against extradition from Kenya that Gilbert Deya faces, nor of the fact that his wife is guilty of child trafficking, although these facts have gathered more attention elsewhere (http://www.thirdsector.co.uk/charity-commission-investigates-charity-sells-healing-olive-oil/governance/article/1406256 http://www.itv.com/news/london/2016-01-25/archbishop-of-peckham-defiant-after-sting-reveals-fake-cancer-cure-claims/) Several of the cost items look surprisingly high - e.g. interest payable of £137k or legal fees of £85k. The interest of £137k and the depreciation of £54k may in fact be fine, given that the balance sheet seems to indicate that the charity does own property, however this would raise the question of why the charity needed to spend over £100k on rent. Overall, it looks suspicious.
300,000 is the number of young people enrolled in DofE at the end of the year. DofE seems to feature "new entrants" and "completed awards" more prominently though.

column47: The number of loans greatly exceeds the target of 4000 - my initial worry was that perhaps too much lending was happening. The next sentence indicated that the loan repayment rate was 100%, which should provide some comfort that the loans are not being given out too liberally (although it's still possible that the loans of an older vintage are of high quality, and the more recent loans include some that should not have been made)

Counting beneficiaries for this project is hard, because the wording in the accounts is "At the end of the first year 570 loans had been made, 946 savings accounts opened, 1,380 people trained in financial literacy" - I have not added the number of people trained in financial literacy as well, since I expect that there are few people who got the financial training without a financial product.

column47: The cup trust has now been all but wound down, however I looked at the most recent set of accounts available, which is a few years old. The activities gave no indication of the number of beneficiaries. In fact, very unusually, it made no meaningful mention of any charitable activity at all - any talk about activity was focused on raising funds. The language was defensive. And the reserves were surprisingly small given the amount of income. When I tried to understand anything about the financial position, I was flummoxed by the fact that the charity received £78.9m, and then "spent" £78.9m on "buying gilts". Bizarrely, after buying the gilts, the money seems to have just vanished, thus breaking a fundamental of accounting (and a rule of how the world works) namely after you buy gilts, you have gilts. The Cup Trust bought gilts and this caused money to disappear. This set of accounts reeked so horrifically that I'm surprised nobody noticed it for so long

column20: Documents of analysis from the GiveWell charity site. - cost-effectiveness analysis can also be accessed from here: http://www.givewell.org/how-we-work/our-criteria/cost-effectiveness/cost-effectiveness-models
column23: SMC focuses on 4 cycles of treatment (1 cycle= 3 doses of the chemotherapeutic drug) along the 4 months when malaria is most prevalent. This refers to the cost required to complete all 4 cycles of treatment for the target cohort.
column25: death(s) averted for children aged under 5
column27: extra income received in the future because children develop better because of having better health
column46: We couldn't find the information we need from Malaria Consortium's own accounts and notes. Therefore, data taken from GiveWell.
column47: Data re cost to treat one child (impact 1): Taken from Source 1 (Sheet: SMC, row 19 of https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1TZ-9eP0et9eYPRj2il4l1UCGS3xmqWarucW5UKQCBIU/edit#gid=1537947274) describes the cost involved in providing all 4 cycles of the treatment plan to children aged under 5. Data re cost to avert the death of an under 5 child: Taken from Source 1 (Sheet: SMC, row 41 - SoGive calculated the median of the values in that row); this row describes the cost involved in averting one death in the cohort population by providing them with all 4 cycles of treatment. GiveWell's analysis also refers to "developmental benefits" -- i.e. the idea that children receiving SMC (treatment against malaria) will develop better through their childhood and therefore earn more in later life, however we have not included the quantification of this in SoGive's database

column58: UK children and young people are facing challenges in their lives as a result of illness, disability or social circumstances. Childlife helps to improve the lives of children and young people by raising funds for the work of its four member charities.

Guideposts Trust offers essential information, help and support to people with learning disabilities, dementia and age related conditions, mental health conditions, and their carers. We aim to enable them to live as independently as possible, with a sense of purpose and achievement. We also provide support to carers helping them cope with their caring role.

We are the UK charity for people affected by 60 different muscle-wasting conditions. We support high-quality research to find effective treatments and cures for all conditions, we ensure access to specialist NHS care and we provide services and opportunities that enable individuals and families to live as independently as possible.

SignHealth works to improve the health and wellbeing of deaf people. Our services include psychological therapy in British Sign Language, residential care homes and support for women survivors of abuse. We campaign for better access to healthcare for deaf people, provide health information in BSL and schools for deaf children in Uganda.

column1: The Roy Castle Lung Cancer Foundation
column58: We are the only charity in the UK wholly dedicated to the defeat of lung cancer. We give help and hope to people affected by lung cancer. We fund research into the early detection of the disease, help people to quit smoking and campaign for better outcomes for lung cancer patients.

column58: Refuge is a United Kingdom charity providing specialist support for women and children experiencing domestic violence. Refuge provides a national network of specialist services, including emergency refuge accommodation (refuges), community outreach, independent domestic violence advocacy (IDVAs), culturally specific services and a team of child support workers. Refuge also runs the Freephone 24-Hour National Domestic Violence Helpline in partnership with Women's Aid.

column58: Climate Outreach aims at ensuring that climate change and it's impacts are understood, accepted and acted upon across the breadth of the society.
column59: Climate Outreach (previously known as COIN) is a charitable company that aims at increasing public understanding and awareness of climate change. They do this by means of three major themes. The first is Communicating Climate change where they communicate about climate change via research, consultation, workshops and training programmes. The second is by supporting individuals and groups in addressing challenges raised by climate change and finding effective ways of engaging with wide-ranging groups to address the social reality of climate change.  Climate change and social justice, the third theme highlights the voices and realities of those affected. With the principles to Innovate, Collaborate and bringing about Social change, Climate Outreach has been operating since 2004 to bring about mass change in the way climate change is addressed and approached.

column60: 92-year-old Joseph from Sandwell, near Birmingham, was referred to Age UK by a local community officer after his wife of 64 years died. Even though Joseph felt he didn't need any help, Age UK refused to give up on him. Someone from Age UK Sandwell went to meet Joseph and see how he was. Although his general mental and emotional wellbeing was clearly very low, Joseph didn’t really want anyone to come and visit. Age UK then arranged for a friendship scheme coordinator to visit Joseph twice more and eventually persuaded him to give befriending a try. Derek started to visit Joseph and they hit it off almost immediately, finding lots of common topics to chat about. He now visits Joseph every week for at least 2 hours and they’ve been able to go on trips together occasionally, too – such as the National Memorial arboretum. Age UK Sandwell also arranged for Joseph to visit the local lunch club and he's made some new friends in the  area. Plus, he’s started gardening again, with a little kickstart from Age UK Sandwell’s gardeners who helped clear the undergrowth - this has also lead to trips to the local garden centre with Derek. Joseph doesn't really like admitting that he was lonely - he's a proud man who fought in WW2 and is highly decorated. He says now that he was too embarrassed to admit he needed help and friends and is extremely grateful to Age UK Sandwell who ‘refused to give up on him’.

column58: ABF Soldiers' charity benefits soldiers, ex-soldiers and those closest to them
column59: ABF Soldiers' charity benefits soldiers, ex-soldiers and those closest to them. It does this by making grants, which either go to individual soldiers and their families, or to other charities, who then use the funds to do work which also relates to supporting the military. Grants are provided for a very wide range of needs including support to those wounded on current or long past operations; help with providing retraining for civilian occupations —especially for those leaving the Army as a result of injury or illness; help for the elderly (through assistance with mobility aids, home adaptations and care home fees); help in covering priority debts such as council tax, utility bills for those in particular difficulty and support for children's education for families in particular need, for example after the death ofthe family bread winner.

column58: Brooke is an international animal welfare charity working to improve the lives of working horses, donkeys, mules and the people who depend on them
column59: Brooke is an international animal welfare charity dedicated to improving the lives of working horses, donkeys and mules. Operating in Africa, Asia, Latin America and the Middle East, they reach over 2 million working horses, donkeys and mules, which they assert is more than any other organisation. They employ around 900 staff worldwide, including vets, animal welfare experts and development specialists. Their work is mostly focused on direct work with animals, although they also do campaigning and research work
